questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the dermatology clinic for evaluation of a skin lesion. He does not have pain, itching, or discharge from the lesion. He states that it has been present since birth, and he has not noted any significant changes in its appearance. Past medical history includes testicular cancer treated with orchiectomy five years ago. Family history is unremarkable. Vital signs are within normal limits.  Physical examination shows a 0.5 cm, single, well-demarcated reddish-brown papule inferior to the left breast. Both breasts and axilla appear normal. Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of this patient’s presentation?  


Reproduced from Wikipedia

choices.text: Obliteration of the milk line during embryogenesis
Inflammation of the sebaceous glands of Montgomery
Failed involution of the mammary ridge

questions.solution:
The most common congenital breast condition in males and females is polythelia (supernumerary nipples), which results from the mammary ridge's failure to involution. The most common site for accessory nipples lies just inferior to the normal breast. Accessory nipples are usually asymptomatic, and excision is not required.  

Another related condition is polymastia (supernumerary breasts). This condition refers to more petite than usual breasts that consist of only a rudimentary nipple and areola (often mistaken for a mole). Supernumerary breasts can appear anywhere along a line that extends from the axilla to the groin along the milk line (location of embryonic mammary crest cells from which the breasts develop). The most common site for polymastia is the lower axilla.  



Option Analysis

❌ Obliteration of the milk line during embryogenesis:
Incorrect: Obliteration of the milk line during embryogenesis can result in athelia, for example, the absence of a nipple or amastia (i.e. absence of breast tissue). This patient’s presentation is consistent with an accessory nipple.  
❌ Inflammation of the sebaceous glands of Montgomery:
Incorrect: Inflammation of the sebaceous glands of Montgomery presents with tender, palpable abscesses over the periphery of the areola. This patient’s breast examination is unremarkable.  
❌ Abnormal response to gonadal hormones:
Incorrect: Abnormal response to gonadal hormones results in spontaneous overgrowth of breast tissue. Overgrowth may be unilateral or symmetric (more common) and begins around puberty. This patient’s breasts appear normal.  
✅ Failed involution of the mammary ridge  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Clonal proliferation of benign melanocytes:
Incorrect: Benign melanocytic nevi result from the clonal proliferation of benign melanocytes. They are usually small or medium-sized, solitary, and may occur anywhere on the skin. This patient’s examination findings are suggestive of an accessory nipple.

questions.text: As part of a research project, the uterus is examined histologically during different phases of the menstrual cycle. Which of the following is true regarding the physiology behind the menstrual cycle?

choices.text: The endometrial glands tend to be more dilated and coiled in the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle.
The endometrial glands tend to be more dilated and coiled in the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle
The stroma of the functional layer tends to be less cellular in the proliferative phase
The proliferative phase is the only phase where the functional layer is regenerating
During the menstrual phase, the functional layer, and the basal layer are lost

questions.solution:
The endometrium is the innermost layer of the uterus and is made up of simple columnar epithelium. The endometrium is further divided into 2 layers, which are the functional layer (outer layer that is lost during menstruation) and the basal layer (attached to the myometrium and is not lost during menstruation).  

The functional layer of the endometrium is lined with simple columnar epithelium (which can be ciliated near the top), the endometrial glands (which are formed by evagination of the surface columnar epithelium and extends down to the basal layer), and stroma (containing blood vessels and supporting cells).  

However, the structure of the functional layer actually varies and undergoes significant changes during the phases of the menstrual cycle in order to prepare itself to receive an embryo.  

During the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle, the endometrium starts proliferating to replace the layer lost as a result of the prior menstrual cycle. Here the functional layer is thin, and the stroma tends to be more cellular. The endometrial glands are also thin and straight during the proliferative phase with a narrow lumen.  

In the secretory phase, the endometrial glands begin secreting glycogen, which causes these glands to dilate and eventually coil. The dilated and coiled glands are the hallmark histological features of the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle.  

Finally, if no embryo implants in the uterus, the functional layer is shed in menstruation, and this is known as the menstrual phase. Here, the functional layer tends to be very thin.  


Option Analysis

✅ The endometrial glands tend to be more dilated and coiled in the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The endometrial glands tend to be more dilated and coiled in the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle  :
Incorrect: The endometrial glands tend to be thin and straight in the proliferative phase.  
❌ The stroma of the functional layer tends to be less cellular in the proliferative phase   :
Incorrect: In the proliferative phase, the stroma tends to be more cellular.  
❌ The proliferative phase is the only phase where the functional layer is regenerating  :
Incorrect: Regeneration of the functional layer begins in the proliferative phase, and continues in the secretory phase.  
❌ During the menstrual phase, the functional layer, and the basal layer are lost  :
Incorrect: In the menstrual phase, the functional layer is shed and lost. However, the basal layer remains attached and aids in the regeneration of the functional layer for the next menstrual cycle.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist for a routine well-visit. She is sexually active with multiple male partners and uses an intrauterine device for contraception. A decision is made to perform a routine pap smear. The region sampled during the pap smear is shown below. Which of the following best describes the region sampled in the pap smear and its corresponding histological epithelium?
questions.solution:
The cervix is the lower, cylindrical part of the uterus that opens into the vagina. Histologically, the cervix is different from the rest of the uterus and has a mucosa that does not shed during menstruation. The cervical mucosa can be separated into three distinct regions: the endocervix, the transformation zone, and the ectocervix.    

- The endocervical mucosa forms the walls of the cervical canal and has a mucus-secreting simple columnar epithelium.   

- The ectocervical mucosa is present in the part of the cervix that protrudes into the upper vagina and surrounds the external os, which is the lower opening of the uterus.     This mucosa will have a non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium that’s continuous with the vagina.   

- The transformation zone is the region between the endo- and ectocervix. There’s an abrupt change from columnar cells to squamous cells within the transformation           zone called the squamocolumnar junction.   

The exact location of the squamocolumnar junction will change or shift depending on the age of the individual as well as changes in the size of the uterus during menstruation. The transformation zone is the ideal site to collect cells from during a Pap smear or Pap test.  

Figure shows the squamocolumnar junction of the cervix, with abrupt transition. The ectocervix, with its 
stratified squamous epithelium, is visible on the left. Simple columnar epithelium, typical of the endocervix, 
is visible on the right. A layer of connective tissue is visible under both types of epithelium.  

Option Analysis

❌ Endocervix; simple columnar epithelium only  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Endocervix only is not commonly sampled in pap smears.
❌ Ectocervix; stratified squamous epithelium only  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Ectocervix only is not commonly sampled in pap smears.  
✅ Transformation zone; squamocolumnar junction  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Uterus; simple columnar epithelium  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Uterine tissue is not commonly sampled in pap smears.  
❌ Vagina; stratified squamous epithelium  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Vaginal tissue is not commonly sampled in pap smears.

questions.text: The menstrual cycle refers to the regular changes in the activity of the ovaries and endometrium that make reproduction possible. Which of the following days in an average 28-day cycle usually represents the day of ovulation?
questions.solution:
The menstrual cycle refers to the regular changes in the activity of the ovaries and endometrium that make reproduction possible.

The menstrual cycle actually consists of two interconnected and synchronized processes: the ovarian cycle, which centers on the development of the ovarian follicles and ovulation; and the endometrial cycle, which centers on endometrial thickening and thinning in response to ovarian activity.

The monthly menstrual cycle can vary in duration from 20 to 35 days, with an average duration of 28 days. Each menstrual cycle begins on the first day of menstruation, which is referred to as day 1 of the cycle.

Ovulation usually occurs 14 days after the first day of menstruation (i.e., 14 days before the next cycle begins). For an average 28-day menstrual cycle, there are usually 14 days leading up to ovulation (preovulatory phase) and 14 days following ovulation (postovulatory phase).  


Option Analysis

❌ Day 1:
Incorrect: Each menstrual cycle begins on the first day of menstruation and this is referred to as day one of the cycle.  
❌ Day 5:
Incorrect: On average, menstruation stops around day 5 of the menstrual cycle and the follicular (proliferative phase) begins around this time.  
✅ Day 14  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Day 20:
Incorrect: Ovulation typically occurs around day 14 of the menstrual cycle, as opposed to day 20.  
❌ Day 25:
Incorrect: Around day 25, if fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum degenerates into a nonfunctional corpus albicans that does not synthesize hormones. Eventually, estrogen and progesterone levels decrease and lead to the beginning of a new menstrual cycle at around day 28.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents for evaluation of amenorrhea that has been ongoing for the past 12 months. She has also experienced dyspareunia, recurrent headaches, and infrequent episodes of night sweats. The patient is subsequently diagnosed with menopause. Which of the following laboratory findings is most specific to this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Menopause is the permanent cessation of menstruation due to loss of ovarian follicular function. It is diagnosed retrospectively after 12 months of amenorrhea. Menopause usually sets in around age 50 and is preceded by a couple of years of hormonal and physical changes, which is termed perimenopause.

During menopause, there is a decrease in serum estrogen production due to an age-linked decline in the number of ovarian follicles. The pituitary gland responds by producing greater amounts of both FSH and LH in an attempt to drive ovarian function. The increase in FSH is specific for menopause and results from loss of negative feedback on FSH due to decreased estrogen levels. Similar to estrogen, progesterone and testosterone levels also fall during menopause.

Common symptoms of menopause include hot flashes, night sweats, mood swings, headaches, and atrophic vaginitis (pruritis or dyspareunia). Menopause also increases the risk of developing coronary artery disease and osteoporosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Increase in serum estrogen levels:
Incorrect: Menopause is associated with a decrease in serum estrogen production due to an age-linked decline in the number of ovarian follicles.  
❌ Decrease in serum LH levels:
Incorrect: Serum LH increases during menopause due to the loss of negative feedback. However, this finding is not specific to menopause.  
✅ Increase in serum FSH levels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decrease in GnRH levels:
Incorrect: Serum GnRH increases in menopause due to the loss of negative feedback from estrogen.
❌ Increase in testosterone levels:
Incorrect: Testosterone levels decrease with menopause. Estrogen levels drop by a greater amount in comparison, leading to an increased androgen-to-estrogen ratio that manifests with androgen-associated symptoms such as facial hair and deeper voice.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the office because of trouble sleeping at night. For the past 2 months, the patient has awakened completely soaked in sweat almost every night. She also reports dyspareunia and “little to no menses” for the past 8 months. She works as an accountant and finds it difficult to concentrate. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. Current medications include lisinopril and over-the-counter multivitamin medications. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg. Physical examination is noncontributory. Pelvic examination reveals a small anteverted uterus and minimal vaginal rugations. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Serum TSH is 3.2 µU/mL. An elevation in which of the following laboratory values would most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with amenorrhea, hot flashes, night sweats, dyspareunia and difficulty concentrating at work, in combination with physical examinations findings of minimal vaginal rugations, is consistent with menopause.

Menopause is defined as absent menses for 12 months in women over 45 years of age. It usually sets in around age 50 and is preceded by an average of 4 years of hormonal and physiologic changes termed perimenopause. During the menopausal transition, FSH levels increase due to the lack of negative feedback from estrogen and progesterone. This period is characterized by amenorrhea, anovulation, hot flashes, and vaginal dryness. Menopause is a clinical diagnosis, and an elevated FSH is not necessary to make it, though it is a reliable clinical indicator. Menopausal symptoms before the age of 40 is abnormal and is usually secondary to primary ovarian insufficiency.

There are a number of long-term effects of estrogen deficiency, including osteoporosis and cardiovascular disease.  

Option Analysis

❌ Progesterone:
Incorrect: Menopause is characterized by decreased levels of progesterone due to decreasing ovarian function.
❌ Estradiol:
Incorrect: Menopause is characterized by gradual decline in the levels of estradiol due to decreasing ovarian function. Estradiol is not a reliable indicator of menopause due to typical fluctuations.
✅ Follicle-stimulating hormone:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Testosterone :
Incorrect: Testosterone levels also decrease with menopause because less estrogen is produced by ovaries, so less is then aromatized to testosterone.
❌ Prolactin:
Incorrect: Serum prolactin levels are elevated in the case of a prolactinoma, which is characterized by additional symptoms of galactorrhea and headache, not seen in this patient. Moreover, prolactin levels are less significantly changed than FSH levels during menopause.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the effects of hormones during different stages of the menstrual cycle. Which of the following is most accurate regarding the uterine cycle?

choices.text: The proliferative phase corresponds to the ovarian luteal phase
Estrogen from the corpus luteum causes lamina propria edema and endometrial thickening
The highest chance of fertilization is between day 1 and day 5 of an average 28-day cycle
During the proliferative phase, estrogen stimulates endometrial thickening and the emergence of spiral arteries
During the proliferative phase, cervical mucus thickens and becomes less hospitable to sperm

questions.solution:
The monthly menstrual cycle averages around 28 days and begins on the first day of menstruation. It has two different cycles: the ovarian cycle and the endometrial cycle. The phases of the uterine cycle include:

-Proliferative phase (corresponds to ovarian follicular phase): Following the menstrual period, high estrogen levels (produced by ovarian follicles) stimulate endometrial thickening and growth of endometrial glands. In addition, there is a slight growth of spiral arteries (due to the influence of estrogen), which help supply the growing functional endometrium. Rising estrogen levels also make the cervical mucus more hospitable to incoming sperm. The combined effects of this spike in estrogen on the uterus and cervix help to optimize the chance of fertilization, which is highest between day 11 and day 15 of an average 28-day cycle.  


-Secretory phase (corresponds to ovarian luteal phase): Under the influence of progesterone secreted by the corpus luteum, the uterus enters the secretory phase of the endometrial cycle. The spiral arteries grow significantly and become coiled, whereas the uterine glands begin to secrete more mucus. After day 15 of the cycle, the optimal window for fertilization begins to close. The cervical mucus starts to thicken and becomes less hospitable to the sperm. If the oocyte is not fertilized, the corpus luteum gradually degenerates into the nonfunctional corpus albicans, which do not produce hormones. When progesterone reaches its lowest level, the spiral arteries collapse, and the functional layer of the endometrium prepares to shed through menstruation.  


Option Analysis

❌ The proliferative phase corresponds to the ovarian luteal phase:
Incorrect: The period of rapid growth during the uterine cycle, the proliferative phase, corresponds to the ovarian follicular phase.  
❌ Estrogen from the corpus luteum causes lamina propria edema and endometrial thickening:
Incorrect: Progesterone (not estrogen) from the corpus luteum causes lamina propria edema and endometrial thickening.  
❌ The highest chance of fertilization is between day 1 and day 5 of an average 28-day cycle:
Incorrect: The highest chance of fertilization is between day 11 and day 15 of an average 28-day cycle. In contrast, day 1-5 corresponds to menstruation.  
✅ During the proliferative phase, estrogen stimulates endometrial thickening and the emergence of spiral arteries  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ During the proliferative phase, cervical mucus thickens and becomes less hospitable to sperm:
Incorrect: After day 15 of the cycle (secretory phase), the optimal window for fertilization begins to close. The cervical mucus starts to thicken and becomes less hospitable to the sperm.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the effects of hormones during different stages of the menstrual cycle. Which of the following is most accurate regarding the ovarian cycle?

choices.text: Production of estrogen and inhibin during ovulation results in a decline in follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)
During the mid-follicular stage, follicular cells differentiate into the corpus luteum
Maximal levels of progesterone production are observed in the mid-luteal phase
The ovarian follicular phase corresponds to the secretory phase of the endometrium
The luteinizing hormone (LH) surge usually happens a day or two after ovulation

questions.solution:
The monthly menstrual cycle averages around 28 days and begins on the first day of menstruation. It has two different cycles: the ovarian cycle and the endometrial cycle. The phases of the ovarian cycle include:

-Follicular phase (corresponds to menstrual and proliferative phases of the endometrium): It refers to the first 2-weeks of a four-week cycle. After days 1-7 of the menstrual cycle, low levels of estradiol and progesterone allow GnRH pulses to induce secretion of increasing amounts of FSH, which then initiate the development of several ovarian follicles. As the follicles grow and estrogen is released into the bloodstream, increased estrogen levels act as negative feedback on FSH secretion.

As a result, some of the developing ovarian follicles will stop growing, regress, and die off. However, one dominant follicle will continue to grow and undergo ovulation. It secretes estrogen, making the pituitary more responsive to the pulsatile action of GnRH from the hypothalamus. The pituitary in response secretes FSH and LH. This surge (LH surge) usually happens a day or two before ovulation (around day 14) and is responsible for stimulating ovarian follicle rupture and the release of the oocyte.

-Luteal phase (corresponds to secretory phase of the endometrium): Following ovulation (day 14), the remnant of the ovarian follicle becomes the corpus luteum. The luteinized granulosa cells secrete more progesterone than estrogen during the luteal phase.

Progesterone acts as a negative feedback signal on the pituitary, decreasing the release of FSH and LH. It also secretes inhibin, which similarly inhibits the release of FSH and LH. These changes result in a decline in estrogen levels and a rise in progesterone levels. If the oocyte is not fertilized, the corpus luteum gradually degenerates into the nonfunctional corpus albicans that do not make hormones. Eventually, estrogen and progesterone levels decrease, leading to the beginning of a new menstrual cycle.
 
 

Option Analysis

❌ Production of estrogen and inhibin during ovulation results in a decline in follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)  :
Incorrect: During the mid-follicular phase, follicles produce greater amounts of estrogen and inhibin. These changes lead to a decline in follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels through negative feedback.  
❌ During the mid-follicular stage, follicular cells differentiate into the corpus luteum:
Incorrect: Following ovulation (not during the mid-follicular stage), the remaining follicular cells differentiate into the corpus luteum.  
✅ Maximal levels of progesterone production are observed in the mid-luteal phase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The ovarian follicular phase corresponds to the secretory phase of the endometrium  :
Incorrect: The ovarian follicular phase corresponds to the menstrual and proliferative phases of the endometrium.  
❌ The luteinizing hormone (LH) surge usually happens a day or two after ovulation  :
Incorrect: The surge in luteinizing hormone (LH) levels usually happens a day or two before ovulation.

questions.text: Estrogen and progesterone are the female sex hormones and are produced mainly by the ovaries. Which of the following enzymes are involved in the conversion of testosterone to estradiol?
questions.solution:
Estrogen is one of the female sex hormones and is produced mainly by the ovaries. The female body can synthesize three types of estrogens: estradiol, estrone, and estriol.    

Estrogen is a steroid hormone and its production starts with cholesterol. Cholesterol reaches the theca cells, where the enzyme cholesterol desmolase converts cholesterol to pregnenolone. Another enzyme in theca cells called 3ꞵ-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase converts some of the pregnenolone to progesterone.  

However, most of the pregnenolone is converted to 17-hydroxypregnenolone, and then into dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA). 3ꞵ-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase also acts on DHEA and converts it into androstenedione (a testosterone precursor).  

Androstenedione diffuses to nearby granulosa cells, which have two enzymes of their own. The first is 17ꞵ-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase, which converts androstenedione to testosterone, and the second is aromatase, which converts testosterone into 17ꞵ-estradiol - the most biologically active type of estrogen.  



Option Analysis

❌ Cholesterol desmolase:
Incorrect: Cholesterol desmolase converts cholesterol to pregnenolone.  
❌ 3ꞵ-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: 3ꞵ-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase converts pregnenolone to progesterone and dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) to androstenedione.  
❌ 17ꞵ-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: 17ꞵ-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase converts androstenedione to testosterone.  
✅ Aromatase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 5α-reductase:
Incorrect: 5α-reductase converts testosterone to dihydrotestosterone.

questions.text: The production of estrogen involves coordinated enzymatic activities between the theca and granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle. Which of the following most appropriately describes the function of estrogen?

choices.text: Prepares uterus for implantation during luteal phase
Facilitates development of internal and external genitalia

questions.solution:
Estrogen is a female sex hormone produced mainly by the ovaries. The estrogen receptors are members of the superfamily of steroid hormone receptors found primarily in the nucleus.  

Pulsatile release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) from the hypothalamus stimulates the pulsatile pituitary release of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). Both FSH and LH stimulate ovarian production of estradiol and progesterone. The variations in pulsatile release of the gonadotropins result in a cyclic response of ovarian function. Each cycle lasts 28 days and can be divided into two phases of 14 days each. During the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, estrogen makes the superficial layer of the uterus (endometrium) thicken up and sprout progesterone receptors. It also acts as a negative feedback signal, making the pituitary secrete less FSH as estrogen levels rise.  

Right before ovulation, the markedly high estrogen levels make the pituitary much more sensitive to the actions of hypothalamic GnRH. These changes result in a positive feedback signal, leading to a massive surge of FSH and LH that leads to ovulation.  

During the luteal phase, progesterone binds to receptors in the endometrium and stimulates the endometrial glands to produce more secretions, which prepare the uterus for a potential pregnancy. Progesterone acts as a negative feedback signal during the luteal phase - making the pituitary secrete less LH. In turn, the levels of progesterone decrease as well, and menstruation follows.  

Estrogen promotes the development of internal/external genitalia, endometrial proliferation, and increases watery cervical mucus production. In the ovaries, it exerts potent mitotic effects on granulosa cells. In the breast, estrogen stimulates growth and differentiation of the ductal epithelium, induces mitotic activity of ductal cylindrical cells, and stimulates the growth of connective tissue. Other estrogen functions are summarized below:  



Option Analysis

❌ Prepares uterus for implantation during luteal phase:
Incorrect: During the luteal phase, progesterone prepares the uterus for implantation of a fertilized egg by stimulating endometrial glandular secretions and spiral artery development.  
❌ Prevents endometrial hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Estrogen enhances endometrial proliferation, whereas progesterone prevents endometrial hyperplasia.  
✅ Facilitates development of internal and external genitalia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreases myometrial excitability in pregnancy:
Incorrect: Progesterone decreases myometrial excitability during pregnancy by reducing contraction frequency and intensity. Estrogen, on the other hand, increased myometrial excitability.
❌ Produces thick cervical mucus:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the function of progesterone. Progesterone induces the production of thick cervical mucus that inhibits sperm entry into the uterus.

questions.text: Primordial germ cells are an essential part of ovarian development. After the primordial cells reach the gonad, they continue to multiply through successive mitotic divisions. Which of the following statements is most appropriate regarding oogenesis?

choices.text: The primary oocyte is arrested in metaphase I until puberty
Pituitary FSH makes the granulosa cells produce more androstenedione
The maximal number of oogonia is achieved at the 20th week of gestation
Meiosis I is completed in the oocyte destined for ovulation in response to the FSH surge
Meiosis II is completed after ovulation regardless of fertilization

questions.solution:
In the fetal period, once the primordial germ cells arrive in the gonad, they differentiate into oogonia. All oogonia either develop into primary oocytes or become atretic (degenerate). The maximal number of oogonia is achieved at the 20th week of gestation, at which time 6 to 7 million oogonia are present in the ovary. Approximately 1 to 2 million oogonia are present at birth. Fewer than 400,000 are present at the initiation of puberty, of which fewer than 500 are destined to ovulate.    

Mitotic division of oogonia increases the population. Many oogonia further differentiate into primary oocytes, which begin meiosis. However, the process arrests after only prophase I is completed. In childhood, primary oocytes remain suspended in prophase I. A primary oocyte with its surrounding epithelial cells is called a primordial follicle. Beginning in puberty and extending through the reproductive years, several primordial follicles mature each month into primary follicles. A few of these continue development to secondary follicles. One or two secondary follicles progress to a tertiary or Graafian follicle stage. The first meiotic division completes this stage to produce a haploid secondary oocyte and a polar body. During this process, cytoplasm is conserved by the secondary oocyte. Consequently, the polar body is disproportionately small. The secondary oocyte halts meiosis at prophase II. One of the secondary oocytes is then released at ovulation. If the oocyte is fertilized by sperm, completion of the second meiotic division follows. If fertilization fails to occur, the oocyte degenerates before the second meiotic division is completed.  



Option Analysis

❌ The primary oocyte is arrested in metaphase I until puberty:
Incorrect: The primary oocyte is arrested in prophase I until puberty.  
❌ Pituitary FSH makes the granulosa cells produce more androstenedione:
Incorrect: Pituitary FSH makes the granulosa cells produce more estrogen. LH release stimulates the formation of androstenedione.  
✅ The maximal number of oogonia is achieved at the 20th week of gestation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Meiosis I is completed in the oocyte destined for ovulation in response to the FSH surge:
Incorrect: Meiosis I is completed in the oocyte destined for ovulation in response to the LH surge.
❌ Meiosis II is completed after ovulation regardless of fertilization:
Incorrect: Meiosis II is completed only if the ovum is fertilized.

questions.text: Progesterone is a steroid hormone and its production starts with cholesterol. It is responsible for the luteal changes in the endometrium and the cyclical changes in the cervix and vagina. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement regarding the functions of progesterone?

choices.text: Decreases the action of prolactin on breast tissue
Stimulates endometrial glandular secretions during menses
Development of internal and external genitalia
Increases maternal IGF-1 concentrations during pregnancy

questions.solution:
Progesterone is a steroid hormone and its production starts with cholesterol. It is secreted by the corpus luteum, placenta, and follicles (in small amounts).  

Progesterone released by corpus luteum acts as a negative feedback signal on the pituitary, decreasing the release of FSH and LH. It also secretes inhibin, which prevents FSH and LH release.These effects result in a decline in estrogen levels and a rise in progesterone levels. If the oocyte is fertilized, the corpus luteum keeps secreting progesterone. If the oocyte is not fertilized, the corpus luteum gradually degenerates into the nonfunctional corpus albicans that do not synthesize progesterone.  

The principal target organs of progesterone are the uterus, breasts, and brain. During the luteal phase, progesterone stimulates endometrial glandular secretions and spiral artery development to prepare the uterus for implantation of a fertilized egg. It also induces the production of thick cervical mucus that inhibits sperm entry into the uterus. Progesterone decreases the number of estrogen receptors in the endometrium and increases the rate of conversion of 17β-estradiol to less active estrogens. Moreover, progesterone is thermogenic and probably is responsible for the rise in basal body temperature at the time of ovulation.    

During pregnancy, progesterone decreases myometrial excitability due to its antiestrogenic effect, hence maintaining the pregnancy. In the breast, progesterone stimulates the development of lobules and alveoli. It induces the differentiation of estrogen-prepared ductal tissue. However, it inhibits the action of prolactin on the breast until after delivery, when the levels of progesterone and estrogen fall and lactation begins.   

Option Analysis

❌ Increases myometrial excitability in pregnancy:
Incorrect: Progesterone decreases myometrial excitability during pregnancy by reducing contraction frequency and intensity.  
✅ Decreases the action of prolactin on breast tissue:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Stimulates endometrial glandular secretions during menses:
Incorrect: Progesterone stimulates endometrial glandular secretions and spiral artery development during the luteal phase to prepare the uterus for implantation of the fertilized egg.  
❌ Development of internal and external genitalia:
Incorrect: Estrogen is involved in the development of internal and external genitalia, breasts, and female fat distribution.
❌ Increases maternal IGF-1 concentrations during pregnancy:
Incorrect: The placenta makes human placental lactogen (hPL) which is thought to be responsible for the marked rise in maternal plasma insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) concentrations as the pregnancy approaches term.

questions.text: Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is a serum biomarker that can be used to determine the presence or absence of pregnancy. Which of the following best describes the main source of hCG during the initial 2 weeks of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is a heterodimeric (two different subunits) glycoprotein hormone produced by newly fertilized embryos and subsequently by the placenta. hCG has an α-subunit that is identical to the α-subunit of FSH, LH, and TSH and a unique β-subunit. Syncytiotrophoblasts secrete hCG, which is detectable in blood 1 week after fertilization and on home urine tests 2 weeks after fertilization.

Most of the pregnancy tests utilize a monoclonal antibody to the β-subunit of hCG, thereby avoiding interference from the similar FSH and LH α-subunits. Placental hormone secretion generally increases over the course of pregnancy, but hCG peaks at 8–10 weeks of gestation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Syncytiotrophoblasts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypothalamus:
Incorrect: Hypothalamus secretes GnRH which stimulates the release of FSH and LH and acts on the ovaries to produce estrogen and progesterone. It is not the source of hCG.  
❌ Corpus luteum:
Incorrect: Human chorionic gonadotropin is not secreted by the corpus luteum; rather, hCG is required to maintain the function of the corpus luteum and its continued progesterone production.  
❌ Corpus albicans:
Incorrect: The corpus albicans is an ovarian scar composed of connective tissue that forms after the corpus luteum degenerates. It is primarily made of collagen and persists on the ovary for a few months. It does not produce hCG.  
❌ Primordial follicles:
Incorrect: Primordial follicles are inactive follicles and do not produce any hormones.

questions.text: Gestational diabetes develops when the body is not able to produce enough of the hormone insulin during pregnancy. Which of the following hormones released during pregnancy is related to gestational diabetes?
questions.solution:
The placenta makes human placental lactogen (hPL) which counters the effect of maternal insulin to help ensure that there is adequate glucose available in the blood for the fetus. Human placental lactogen is thought to be responsible for the marked rise in maternal plasma insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) concentrations as the pregnancy approaches term.  It exerts metabolic effects during pregnancy via IGF-I. It is associated with insulin resistance, enhanced insulin secretion which stimulates lipolysis, increased circulating free fatty acids, and inhibition of gluconeogenesis. In effect, it antagonizes insulin action, induces glucose intolerance, and results in lipolysis and proteolysis in the maternal system. The elevated blood glucose level in gestational diabetes is caused by this hPL.  

Option Analysis

❌ Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)  :
Incorrect: Human chorionic gonadotropin is secreted by the syncytiotrophoblasts and is important for the maintenance of the pregnancy. It, however, has no role in the development of gestational diabetes.  
❌ Estrogen:
Incorrect: Estrogen is important for the maintenance of the pregnancy. It also prevents other follicles from maturing during the pregnancy.  
❌ Progesterone:
Incorrect: During pregnancy, progesterone is important for the prevention of preterm labor. It also prepares and maintains the endometrium to allow implantation earlier.  
❌ Prolactin:
Incorrect: Prolactin production during pregnancy prepares the mammary glands for lactation once the progesterone levels fall at the end of pregnancy. It has no role in the development of gestational diabetes.  
✅ Human placental lactogen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: During pregnancy, multiple hormones are released to maintain pregnancy and prepare the mammary glands for lactation. Which of the following combinations of hormonal changes occur during parturition?
questions.solution:
During pregnancy, the placenta releases human placental lactogen and progesterone, while the anterior pituitary gland releases prolactin. All three of these hormones stimulate the growth of more glandular tissue and prepare the alveolar cells to produce milk.

However, even though the breasts can make milk by mid-pregnancy, the high levels of progesterone associated with pregnancy prevent milk letdown.

Prolactin helps induce and maintain lactation and inhibits reproductive function. With delivery, there is an abrupt decline in estrogen and progesterone serum levels, which disinhibits prolactin. These changes lead to the initiation of lactation. The intensity and duration of subsequent lactation are controlled, in large part, by the repetitive stimulus of suckling and emptying of milk from the breast. Likewise, oxytocin levels also increase to assist in milk letdown and promote uterine contractions.  

Option Analysis

❌ Increase estrogen and progesterone:
Incorrect: With delivery, there is an abrupt decline in estrogen and progesterone serum levels.  
❌ Increase estrogen and prolactin:
Incorrect: With delivery, there is an abrupt decline in estrogen and progesterone serum levels, which disinhibits prolactin synthesis.  
❌ Increase progesterone and prolactin:
Incorrect: With delivery, there is an abrupt decline in estrogen and progesterone serum levels, which disinhibits prolactin synthesis.
✅ Decrease progesterone and increase prolactin  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decrease oxytocin and prolactin:
Incorrect: With delivery, there is an abrupt decline in estrogen and progesterone serum levels, which disinhibits prolactin synthesis. Oxytocin levels also increase to assist in milk letdown and promote uterine contractions.

questions.text: Normal pregnancy is characterized by adequate physiological adaptations in the mother. Which of the following best describes a normal hematologic change seen during pregnancy?

choices.text: Erythrocyte mass rise is more than blood volume

questions.solution:
Normal hematological adaptations during pregnancy are characterized by a hypercoagulable state due to an increase in blood clotting factors such as fibrinogen, factors V, VII, VIII, X, von Willebrand factor, and thrombin activation, as well as enhanced platelet aggregation–all due to the action of estrogen. At the same time, estrogen decreases the activity of antithrombin III, which normally inhibits coagulation. This hypercoagulable state decreases blood loss during the delivery of the fetus. However, this also means pregnant females have a greater risk of developing venous thromboembolism, especially in the lower legs, where there is already venous stasis.

Pregnancy also increases the risk of micronutrient deficiency (e.g iron and folate) due to increased utilization by the developing fetus.

Lastly, the blood volume increases by 30-50% during pregnancy. This allows increased blood flow to the uterus and developing placenta. Erythrocyte mass rises less significantly, leading to physiologic anemia of pregnancy.  


Option Analysis

❌ Increased activity of antithrombin III  :
Incorrect: During pregnancy, estrogen decreases the activity of antithrombin III, which normally inhibits coagulation.  
✅ Increase in plasma fibrinogen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Development of neutropenia:
Incorrect: During pregnancy, neutrophilic leukocytosis may be seen.  
❌ Blood volume decreases by 10-20%:
Incorrect: During pregnancy, blood volume increases by 30-50%.  
❌ Erythrocyte mass rise is more than blood volume:
Incorrect: During pregnancy, the erythrocyte mass rises less significantly, leading to the physiologic anemia of pregnancy, with typical hemoglobin levels of 10-12 g/dL by term.

questions.text: Pregnancy is defined by the National Institutes of Health, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, and the Food and Drug Administration as implantation of the blastocyst in the endometrium. Which of the following is the most common location for fertilization of the ovum?
questions.solution:
Fertilization is the union of the 2 germ cells, the ovum, and the sperm, restoring chromosome numbers and initiating the development of a new individual. It most commonly occurs in the ampulla, which is the widest section of the fallopian tubes. Fertilization typically occurs within 1 day of ovulation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cervix:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Fertilization does not occur in the cervix.  
❌ Uterus:
Incorrect: It is unusual for fertilization to occur in the uterus. Instead, the blastocyst implants in the uterine wall 6 days after fertilization.  
❌ Isthmus:
Incorrect: The isthmus is the narrow section of the uterine tubes connecting the ampulla to the uterine cavity. It is an uncommon site of fertilization.  
✅ Ampulla:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Infundibulum:
Incorrect: The infundibulum is the funnel-shaped opening near the ovary to which fimbriae are attached. It is an uncommon site of fertilization.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the office for the evaluation of absent menses. She has had a regular 28-day menstrual cycle since the age of 13,  but her last menstrual period occurred 4 months ago. The patient is sexually active with her male partner for 2 years. The patient does not have hot flashes, excessive hair growth or vaginal dryness. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is significant for breast cancer in the maternal aunt. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows fullness of the breasts bilaterally and mild abdominal distension. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient with amenorrhea (absence of a menstrual period in a woman of reproductive age) previously had a normal menstrual cycle of 28 days; therefore, she has secondary amenorrhea. This condition is defined as no menstrual bleeding for at least three normal menstrual cycles in a female who previously had regular cycles or for six months for females who previously had irregular cycles. The most common cause of secondary amenorrhea is pregnancy.

On the other hand, primary amenorrhea is when a female has not had her first menstruation by the age of 16, despite normal growth and having started puberty, or when a female has not had menarche by age 13 and does not show signs of puberty (i.e. development of secondary sexual characteristics: breasts, pubic hair). The most common cause of primary amenorrhea is Turner syndrome.

Other causes of primary and secondary amenorrhea are as follows:


Option Analysis

❌ Kallman syndrome:
Incorrect: Kallmann syndrome results when GnRH-producing neurons fail to migrate from the nose region to the hypothalamus during fetal development. This syndrome causes low levels of GnRH, FSH, and LH, and, as a consequence, low estrogen; thus puberty either never starts or is incomplete. This patient previously had normal menstruation.
❌ Androgen insensitivity syndrome:
Incorrect: In androgen insensitivity syndrome, the individual is karyotypically male, which means they have a 46, XY karyotype, but their androgen receptors do not respond to testosterone. Thus they lack a uterus, fallopian tubes or ovaries and therefore do not menstruate. This patient previously had normal menstruation.  
❌ Polycystic ovarian syndrome:
Incorrect: Polycystic ovarian syndrome is a common cause of secondary amenorrhea. It usually presents with hirsutism, treatment-resistant acne, menstrual irregularities, acanthosis nigricans, and/or obesity. This patient does not have the other findings associated with polycystic ovarian syndrome, making this a less-likely diagnosis.
❌ Primary ovarian insufficiency:
Incorrect: Premature ovarian failure occurs when the ovarian follicles undergo accelerated atresia and become depleted before the age of 40, resulting in early menopause. Patients usually report irregular menses and symptoms of estrogen deficiency such as vaginal dryness and hot flashes. This patient is not having symptoms similar to menopause, making this an unlikely diagnosis.
✅ Pregnancy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: Normal pregnancy physiology is characterized by cardiovascular adaptations in the mother. Which of the following best describes a normal physiologic change seen during pregnancy?

choices.text: A decrease in circulating blood volume by 30-50%
A physiological S4 heart sound is always present
Systolic blood pressure increases by 10-20 mmHg
Increased oncotic pressure due to hemoconcentration

questions.solution:
During the course of pregnancy, to supply an enlarging uterus and a growing fetus, as well as having some reserve for the blood loss that happens during delivery, the cardiovascular system has to expand.

Pregnancy is called a high-volume state because the circulating blood volume increases by 30-50%. To push this extra blood around, the heart rate increases by about 20 beats per minute, so this increases the stroke volume, and therefore the cardiac output. Overall, cardiac output increases by 30–50%, peaking (and remaining constant) around the 14th week of pregnancy. The number of red blood cells increases slightly, but there’s a much larger increase in plasma volume. Therefore, the hematocrit actually goes down, causing “physiological anemia of pregnancy.”

In response to the increased workload, there is mild hypertrophy of the heart, which resolves after pregnancy. The high volume state also explains why there is sometimes a third heart sound, or physiologic S3, as well as a split S1 which is where the mitral valve closes slightly faster than the tricuspid valve. Finally, the blood pressure slightly decreases, even though more blood gets pushed through them since progesterone causes arterioles to dilate.
 
 

Option Analysis

❌ A decrease in circulating blood volume by 30-50%:
Incorrect: Pregnancy is called a high-volume state because the circulating blood volume increases by 30-50%. The expanded plasma volume is thought to meet the increased metabolic demands of the uterus and placenta, facilitate delivery of nutrients to the developing fetus, protect against the effects of impaired venous return when the mother is supine or standing, and protect the mother from excessive blood loss during delivery.  
✅ Increase in cardiac output  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ A physiological S4 heart sound is always present  :
Incorrect: Due to the high volume state in pregnancy, there is sometimes a third heart sound or physiologic S3, as well as a split S1 which is where the mitral valve closes slightly faster than the tricuspid valve.  
❌ Systolic blood pressure increases by 10-20 mmHg  :
Incorrect: During pregnancy, the blood pressure actually slightly falls, even though more blood is getting pushed through the vessels since progesterone causes arterioles to dilate.  
❌ Increased oncotic pressure due to hemoconcentration:
Incorrect: The oncotic pressure drops during pregnancy due to hemodilution leading to the development of peripheral edema.

questions.text: Substantial evidence supports the advantages of breastfeeding over breast milk substitutes (e.g. formula) or early addition of foods. Which of the following statements is most appropriate regarding the recommendations and benefits of breastfeeding?

choices.text: For premature babies, breastfeeding increases the incidence of necrotizing enterocolitis
The benefits of exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months of life are powerful
Colostrum coats the baby’s gastrointestinal tract and has a constipation effect
The amount of vitamin D in breast milk is typically sufficient for the bone health of the infant
Maternal infections like HIV are not a contraindication to breastfeeding

questions.solution:
Substantial evidence supports the advantages of breastfeeding over breast milk substitutes (e.g. formula) or early addition of foods. The benefits of exclusive breastfeeding are powerful for the first six months of life. Breast milk contains secretory IgA, which supplements the baby’s gastrointestinal and immune systems. Breast milk reduces the baby’s risk of developing infections and conditions such as allergies, asthma, and obesity. Moreover, breastfeeding facilitates maternal-child bonding and decreases the risk of maternal breast and ovarian cancer.

However, it should be noted that the amount of vitamin D in breast milk is typically insufficient for bone health. Exclusively breastfed infants may require vitamin D supplementation.

Contraindications to breastfeeding include maternal use of illicit substances (e.g., cocaine, heroin, cannabis). Other harmful substances, such as alcohol and tobacco, can also pass from mother to child via breast milk. Finally, maternal infections (e.g. HIV) are a contraindication to breastfeeding in high-income settings but may be appropriate in low-income settings where the cost of formula and access to clean water are serious challenges.  


Option Analysis

❌ For premature babies, breastfeeding increases the incidence of necrotizing enterocolitis:
Incorrect: For premature babies, breastfeeding reduces the incidence of necrotizing enterocolitis and may enhance their neurocognitive development. 
✅ The benefits of exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months of life are powerful :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Colostrum coats the baby’s gastrointestinal tract and has a constipation effect:
Incorrect: Colostrum coats the baby’s gastrointestinal tract and has a laxative effect.
❌ The amount of vitamin D in breast milk is typically sufficient for the bone health of the infant:
Incorrect: The amount of vitamin D in breast milk is typically insufficient for bone health. Moreover, the primarily indoor lifestyle of modern newborns further prevents vitamin D synthesis. As a result, supplemental vitamin D is often needed. 
❌ Maternal infections like HIV are not a contraindication to breastfeeding:
Incorrect: Maternal infections like HIV are a contraindication to breastfeeding in high-income settings. In contrast, breastfeeding may be appropriate in low-income settings when other factors, such as the cost of formula and access to clean water, are serious challenges.

questions.text: A 25-year-old gravida 1, para 0, is at a gestational age of 20 weeks. Which of the following is the best estimation of the embryonic age of the fetus?
questions.solution:
Embryonic age is the actual age of the growing baby, starting at the time of conception. The age of the fetus is two weeks shorter than the gestational age. Ovulation occurs two weeks after the last menstrual period and fertilization occurs close to ovulation. Therefore, the date of conception lies at the date of ovulation. It is a less accurate measurement due to the difficulty of calculating the date. The length of pregnancy should be 38 weeks according to the embryonic age.  

On the other hand, gestational age is the age of the pregnancy taken from the beginning of the last menstrual period (LMP). It includes an additional two weeks of time when the woman is not pregnant, while fetal age is calculated after conception. It is more accurate than embryonic age. The length of the pregnancy should be 40 weeks according to the gestational age.

Option Analysis

✅ 18 weeks:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 20 weeks:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Embryonic age of the fetus is two weeks shorter than the gestational age as ovulation occurs two weeks after the last menstrual period and fertilization occurs close to ovulation. Therefore, the date of conception lies at the date of ovulation.
❌ 22 weeks:
Incorrect:This answer choice is incorrect. Embryonic age of the fetus is two weeks shorter than the gestational age as ovulation occurs two weeks after the last menstrual period and fertilization occurs close to ovulation. Therefore, the date of conception lies at the date of ovulation.
❌ 24 weeks:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Embryonic age of the fetus is two weeks shorter than the gestational age as ovulation occurs two weeks after the last menstrual period and fertilization occurs close to ovulation. Therefore, the date of conception lies at the date of ovulation.
❌ 26 weeks:
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Embryonic age of the fetus is two weeks shorter than the gestational age as ovulation occurs two weeks after the last menstrual period and fertilization occurs close to ovulation. Therefore, the date of conception lies at the date of ovulation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the family physician with concerns of delayed pubertal development. The patient has not yet had menarche and is concerned she is “falling behind” her classmates. According to her parent, the patient has been previously diagnosed with a chromosomal abnormality. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse 110/min, and blood pressure 130/70 mm Hg. She is at the 5<sup>th</sup> percentile for height. Physical examination reveals a webbed neck, cubitus valgus, and mild lymphedema of the upper extremities. Which of the following best describes the hormonal imbalances associated with this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history and physical examination are notable for a webbed neck, cubitus valgus (abnormality wherein the forearms are angled away from body), lymphedema, short stature, and primary amenorrhea. Furthermore, the patient has been previously diagnosed with a chromosomal abnormality. She likely has Turner syndrome.  

Patients with Turner syndrome are born with either a 45 XO or a mosaic 45 XO and 46 XX genotype. A key feature of Turner syndrome is the formation of streak ovaries. Streak ovaries describe the phenomenon of ovarian dysgenesis where in lieu of normal functional ovaries, patients are left with bands of scar tissue that do not produce hormones. As a result, patients will have reduced levels of estrogen and progesterone, both of which are normally produced by the ovaries. Due to a lack of negative feedback from estrogen and progesterone, patients will, in turn, have elevated FSH and LH levels.  

Due to the aforementioned changes, patients with Turner syndrome will often have primary amenorrhea, or the absence of menstruation. Furthermore, patients may have a delayed development of secondary sexual characteristics.  


Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has physical examination findings suggestive of Turner syndrome. Individuals with Turner syndrome will have ovarian dysgenesis, which would result in reduced estradiol and progesterone levels. Due to the absence of negative feedback from estrogen, FSH and LH levels will in turn be elevated.
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has physical examination findings suggestive of Turner syndrome. Individuals with Turner syndrome will have ovarian dysgenesis, which would result in reduced estradiol and progesterone levels. Due to the absence of negative feedback from estrogen, FSH and LH levels will in turn be elevated.   
❌ :
Incorrect: These findings would be present in a pituitary cause (e.g., prolactinoma, Sheehan syndrome) or hypothalamic cause (e.g., hypothalamic tumor) of amenorrhea. Both types of conditions would cause low FSH and LH levels, which would, in turn, result in reduced estrogen and progesterone levels. In contrast, Turner syndrome causes amenorrhea due to gonadal dysfunction and would instead present with elevated FSH and LH levels.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the findings in a healthy individual. In contrast, this patient has primary amenorrhea secondary to Turner syndrome, which would cause ovarian dysgenesis and decreased estrogen and progesterone levels. Due to the absence of negative feedback from estrogen, FSH and LH levels will in turn be elevated.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is referred to an endocrinologist by his pediatrician due to concerns about the child’s development. The patient’s parents report that he has had pubic, axillary and chest hair growth over the past six months. They note that the child also gained several inches in height over the same period. Currently, the patient is at the 89th percentile for height and 76<sup>th</sup> percentile for weight. Physical examination reveals coarse pubic, chest and axillary hair. The testes are markedly enlarged without evidence of extra-seminal masses. Which of the following findings is most likely to be found on further evaluation?

choices.text: Hypothalamic tumor on MRI of the brain

questions.solution:
Puberty encompasses a wide range of physical, mental and psychological changes that an individual undergoes in response to changes in the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis. Precocious puberty refers to a disorder in which puberty starts far earlier than expected. Specifically, precocious puberty is defined as starting puberty before the age of eight in females and nine in males. Broadly, precocious puberty gets divided into central precocious puberty and peripheral precocious puberty.

Central precocious puberty arises from large amounts of secreted gonadotropin release hormone (GnRH) from the hypothalamus (typically from a hypothalamic tumor). In contrast, peripheral precocious puberty is more often due to a tumor of the peripheral sex organs (namely the adrenal gland or gonads). The gold standard test to confirm a general diagnosis of precocious puberty is an x-ray of the hands or long bones; this should be done prior to pursuing radiographic or laboratory investigations for causes of central or peripheral precocious puberty. This test determines a patient’s bone age, and patients with precocious puberty are known to have advanced bone age. If the bone age is normal, other differentials should be considered including premature thelarche, premature adrenarche, or premature menarche.

Option Analysis

✅ Advanced bone age on radiography  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypothalamic tumor on MRI of the brain  :
Incorrect: While possible, patients with central precocious puberty (e.g. due to dysfunction hypothalamic-pituitary axis) often also present with symptoms of central nervous system dysfunction.  
❌ High circulating exogenous testosterone levels  :
Incorrect: Patients with exogenous testosterone use often present with extreme irritability, robust muscular build, severe acne, and male pattern baldness.  
❌ -1.0 T score on DEXA scan  :
Incorrect: DEXA scanning is used to evaluate bone density and is used frequently in evaluating for osteoporosis. A score of minus one reflects a normal bone density.  
❌ Testicular tumor on ultrasonography  :
Incorrect: A testicular ultrasound may better characterize a testicular tumor thought to be causing peripheral precocious puberty. While this patient has markedly enlarged testicles, evidence of an additional testicular mass is absent.

questions.text: A 31-year-old patient with Turner syndrome presents to the family physician for a routine annual checkup. They now work as a lawyer and have been undergoing routine checkups each year. They are feeling well and take no medications. Temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 72/min, and blood pressure 128/70 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a webbed neck, short stature, curved thoracic spine, and cubitus valgus. Prior ECG and echocardiogram testing demonstrated no abnormalities. Which of the following is this patient at a greater risk of developing?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with Turner syndrome and has several physical examination findings consistent with the diagnosis (e.g., scoliosis, short stature, cubitus valgus). Patients with Turner syndrome are at increased risk of developing a wide variety of symptoms and disorders (see below list).  

In particular, osteoporosis affects patients with Turner syndrome much earlier than average due to a lack of estrogen. Estrogen stimulates osteoblastic activity and is protective of bone development. In its absence, patients are susceptible to osteoporosis and fractures, similar to what is observed in postmenopausal females. This risk of osteoporosis and associated fractures can be reduced in patients with Turner syndrome via estrogen replacement therapy. 

Associated clinical findings with Turner syndrome:  
  • Short stature  
  • Cardiovascular abnormalities  
  • Learning disability  
  • Hearing loss  
  • Renal agenesis/horseshoe kidney  
  • Ovarian failure  
  • Osteoporosis  
  • Scoliosis  
  • Other comorbidities  
    • Celiac disease  
    • Autoimmune thyroiditis  
    • Liver disease  
    • Metabolic syndrome  
    • Gonadoblastoma  

Option Analysis

❌ Bicuspid aortic valve:
Incorrect: A bicuspid aortic valve is often associated with Turner syndrome. However, this patient has an unremarkable echocardiogram, hence making an underlying valvular abnormality unlikely.
❌ Alzheimer disease  :
Incorrect: Patients with trisomy 21 have three copies of the amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene, which is located on chromosome 21, and are subsequently at increased risk for developing Alzheimer disease. In contrast, this patient has Turner syndrome, which is not associated with Alzheimer disease.
✅ Osteoporosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypotension:
Incorrect: Patients with Turner syndrome are at increased risk for hypertension, not hypotension.
❌ Joint hypermobility  :
Incorrect: Joint hypermobility is a feature of Marfan syndrome. The condition arises due to a mutation of the FBN1 gene on chromosome 15. As a result, the body produces an abnormal form of the protein fibrillin, which is a key structure in the formation of elastic fibers in connective tissue. In contrast, this patient has Turner syndrome, which is not typically associated with joint hypermobility.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl was brought to the clinic by her mother due to abdominal and back pain over the past few months. The pain started approximately 6 months ago and since then has progressively worsened. Each month, the patient experiences a few days of severe pain that cause her to miss school. She also discloses pain with defecation and difficulty urinating. The patient had not yet had a menstrual period and is not sexually active. In the office, the patient’s temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 121/73 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is Tanner stage 5 with fully developed female secondary sex characteristics. Suprapubic fullness and tenderness are noted. β-hCG is negative. Which of the following is most likely the cause of this condition?

choices.text: Endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterine cavity
Penetration of glandular tissue into the myometrium

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with primary amenorrhea, cyclic pelvic pain, back pain, dyschezia, and difficulty urinating, as well as suprapubic fullness, all favoring the diagnosis of outlet obstruction due to imperforate hymen.    

The vaginal lumen is parted from the urogenital sinus by the hymenal membrane. Normally, the hymen ruptures before birth due to degeneration of the central portion. Hymenal anomalies occur due to incomplete degeneration of the central portion and include imperforate, microperforate, septate, and cribriform hymens.    

Imperforate hymen results in complete outflow obstruction. At the age of menarche, adolescent girls present with amenorrhea and cyclic abdominal or pelvic pain. Significant distention from blood accumulation (hematocolpos) may result in back pain, dyschezia, and difficulty urinating. On physical examination, a bluish membrane is often observed bulging from the vagina. The diagnosis can be confirmed with translabial or transperitoneal ultrasound. Treatment involves surgical opening of the hymen and evacuation of accumulated material.   

Option Analysis

❌  Endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterine cavity :
Incorrect: These findings describe endometriosis, which commonly occurs in the ovary, pelvis, and peritoneum. Common presenting symptoms include cyclic pelvic pain, bleeding, dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, dyschezia, and infertility. While some of this patient’s symptoms overlap with endometriosis, it does not explain the patient’s suprapubic fullness. Findings suggestive of endometriosis are tenderness on vaginal examination, posterior fornix nodularity, adnexal masses, and immobility of cervix or uterus.   
✅ Outlet obstruction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Uterine adhesions :
Incorrect: Uterine adhesions and/or fibrosis of the endometrium, also known as Asherman syndrome, are associated with intrauterine procedures such as dilation and curettage. Patients may present with decreased fertility, abnormal uterine bleeding, pelvic pain, and recurrent pregnancy loss. This patient has not reached menarche and did not undergo any intrauterine procedures.  
❌ Penetration of glandular tissue into the myometrium :
Incorrect: Penetration of glandular tissue (endometrial tissue) into the myometrium describes adenomyosis. Patients with adenomyosis often present with uterine enlargement, abnormal uterine bleeding, and painful and heavy menses. It is more common in women after 40 years of age. This patient has not yet reached menarche. 
❌ Defect in the androgen receptor:
Incorrect: Androgen-insensitivity syndrome (AIS) is a condition in which a defect in the androgen receptor results in a patient who is phenotypically female (despite 46,XY karyotype), with normal female external genitalia, scant axillary and pubic hair, rudimentary vagina, and absence of the uterus and fallopian tubes. This phenotype is due to the production of anti-Müllerian hormone from normally functioning testes which are often found in the labia majora. While primary amenorrhea also occurs in AIS, it would not explain the patient’s cyclic symptoms and abdominal fullness.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician for a routine checkup. The parents privately express concern about the boy’s academic performance and physical appearance, stating that “He looks kind of different from the other boys at school.” The patient has repeatedly failed reading, writing, and mathematics exams at school and is at risk of being held-back for a year. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 112/73 mmHg, and pulse is 73/min. The patient is at the 99<sup>th </sup>percentile for height. Physical examination reveals bilateral gynecomastia, narrow shoulders, and wide hips. Which of the following is an anticipated feature of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with many characteristic symptoms of Klinefelter syndrome (KS), including gynecomastia, narrow shoulders, wide hips, and learning disability. The condition develops when individuals inherit an extra maternal X chromosome and have a XXY genotype. KS has an estimated prevalence of 1:500 to 1:1000 in phenotypical males.  

 A key feature of KS is infertility. The extra X chromosome leads to the expression of proteins that cause testicular fibrosis and hypoplasia as well as subsequent primary gonadal failure. As a result, there is decreased secretion of inhibin B by the Sertoli cells and testosterone by the Leydig cells of the testes. These abnormalities, in turn, lead to an increase in FSH and LH levels. Furthermore, the extra X chromosome leads to increased estrogen production.  

Typically, individuals with Klinefelter have a eunuchoid body shape, which is characterized by a tall and slim body with long extremities. In addition, patients have reduced muscle mass; less facial, body, and genital hair; and frequently develop gynecomastia.

 Finally, patients with KS are at risk of developing mitral valve prolapse and intellectual disability, although the underlying mechanism remains poorly understood.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Diplopia:
Incorrect: This patient has gynecomastia, narrow shoulders, wide hips, and concerns for intellectual disability. These findings are suggestive of Klinefelter syndrome, which is not associated with diplopia.   
❌ Severe acne  :
Incorrect: Patients with double Y syndrome are at risk for developing severe acne during puberty. Patients with this condition may also have tall stature and intellectual disability. However, the condition would not typically manifest with gynecomastia.  
❌ Lymphedema:
Incorrect: Turner syndrome is associated with lymphatic system abnormalities and can lead to lymphedema, which can manifest with swelling of the hands and feet. However, individuals with Turner syndrome will have a female phenotype and a short, as opposed to tall, stature.   
❌ Joint hypermobility:
Incorrect: Joint hypermobility is a feature of Marfan syndrome. The condition arises due to a mutation of the FBN1 gene on chromosome 15. As a result, the body produces an abnormal form of the protein fibrillin, which is a key structure in the formation of elastic fibers in connective tissue. This patient instead has characteristic features of Klinefelter syndrome.  
✅ Infertility:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to her pediatrician by her parent due to concerns that she has not undergone puberty. The patient feels well, with no specific complaints. Her temperature is 98.3 F°(37 C°), blood pressure of 129/92 mmHg, and a heart rate of 71/min. The physician notes undeveloped breasts and normal appearing genitalia in Tanner stage I of development. She is at the 40<sup>th</sup> percentile for height. A hormone panel is sent and shows an increase in 17-ketosteroids. CT imaging of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrates bilaterally enlarged adrenal glands. Which of the following terms appropriately describes this disorder?
questions.solution:
This 17-year-old patient presents with delayed onset of puberty, a hormonal panel that shows an increase in 17-ketosteroids, and imaging revealing bilaterally enlarged adrenal glands. Together, these findings are suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, a disorder of sexual development (DSD).

DSD encompasses an array of conditions due to aberrations in sexual development, including congenital adrenal hyperplasia, androgen insensitivity syndrome, 5-alpha-reductase-deficiency, ovotesticular disorder, Kleinfelter syndrome, XYY syndrome, mullerian agenesis, and Turner syndrome.

The term DSD, while currently accepted, has also been controversial. The argument over terminology as it pertains to interventions for these conditions, and whether physicians and parents should make irreversible treatment decisions on behalf of children, continues to be debated. Ultimately, this has led to a continued discussion of medical terminology surrounding and defining these conditions.  



Option Analysis

❌ Intersex disorder  :
Incorrect: Although “intersex disorder” was a common term for a larger family of sexual development disorders, this term is dated and considered pejorative. It should be noted that the term has been reclaimed by some individuals when referring to themselves (i.e. someone may identify as “intersex” or as an “intersex person”). However, the proper medical term for the condition in this question is a disorder of sexual development (DSD).  
❌ True hermaphrodite:
Incorrect: “True hermaphrodite” refers to having both male and female external genitalia; however, this term is dated and considered pejorative.  
❌ Pseudohermaphrodite  :
Incorrect: Similar to “true hermaphrodites,” this term refers to having external genitalia incongruent with their karyotype. However, this is considered a dated and pejorative term no longer in use.  
✅ Disorder of sexual development  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Eunuch  :
Incorrect: An eunuch is an antiquated term that refers to a castrated male. This is not a congenital medical disorder.

questions.text: A 34-year-old pregnant primigravid woman at 26 weeks gestation presents to the OB/Gyn clinic. Previous routine checkups done during this pregnancy were unremarkable. An amniocentesis is performed in order to ascertain the karyotype of the child. Ultrasound at the time of the amniocentesis shows a male fetus with head circumference and total body length at the 53<sup>rd</sup> and 67<sup>th</sup> percentile, respectively. The resulting karyotypic analysis reveals the child has an accessory Y chromosome. Which of the following is a key characteristic associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
A karyotype was performed and revealed this patient’s fetus has an accessory Y chromosome. As a result, the karyotype is 47 XYY.  

XYY Syndrome (also termed Jacobs syndrome and double Y syndrome) presents with few symptoms. These can include tall stature, severe acne during puberty, and intellectual disability. Patients are also at increased risk for developing autism spectrum disorder. Overall, individuals with XYY are phenotypically normal and do not have fertility problems. For this reason, the condition is frequently undiagnosed.  

Of note, unlike other chromosomal abnormalities like the trisomies (21, 18, and 13), Triple X syndrome, and Kleinfelter syndrome, XYY syndrome is unrelated to maternal age. There is no correlation since the condition arises due to paternal meiotic nondisjunction, not maternal.  



Option Analysis

❌ Anosmia:
Incorrect: Anosmia is often associated with Kallmann syndrome, which can arise due to defective migration of GnRH-releasing neurons. In contrast, the fetus has an accessory Y chromosome and will likely develop symptoms associated with double Y syndrome.  
❌ Vertebral dislocation  :
Incorrect: Patients with trisomy 21 are at risk for developing atlantoaxial instability, which is instability between the C1 (atlas) and C2 (axis) vertebrae; this instability predisposes patients to vertebral dislocations. Dislocations can be precipitated by intubation, which is why asking about other medical conditions is a key part of the history and physical obtained in the preoperative period.  
✅ Intellectual disability  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.    
❌ Osteoporosis  :
Incorrect: Patients with conditions associated with hypoestrogenemia, such as Turner syndrome, are at risk for developing osteoporosis. In contrast, this patient has double Y syndrome, which would not typically lead to osteoporosis.  
❌ Short stature  :
Incorrect: Double Y syndrome is associated with a tall, not short, stature.

questions.text: A 36-year-old primigravida woman at 17 weeks gestation presents to the obstetrician's office with a chief complaint of severe acne. The patient states that her symptoms started three weeks ago and have progressively worsened. Her friends and family members have noticed her voice deepening as well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Transabdominal ultrasound reveals a female fetus with head circumference at the 57th percentile and body length at the 46th percentile. On physical examination of the patient, coarse dark hair is present on her face, chest and back. Hormone panel testing demonstrates that the patient’s circulating testosterone levels are >70 times the upper limit of normal. Which of the following is a characteristic clinical finding to be expected in the fetus following parturition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with symptoms of hirsutism during pregnancy, characteristic of placental aromatase deficiency. The placenta produces large amounts of androgens which are converted into estrogens. With placental aromatase deficiency, androgens fail to convert into estrogens, and they instead accumulate in both fetal and maternal circulation. Circulating androgen levels in the mother can reach as high as 100 times the upper limits of normal.

Following parturition, symptoms rapidly resolve in the mother. If the fetus is male, the exposure to excess circulating androgens will have no effect on external genital development. If the fetus is female, the excess circulating androgens result in the development of ambiguous genitalia, including labioscrotal fusion and clitoromegaly.  

Option Analysis

❌ No expected abnormalities  :
Incorrect: This is correct in the case of placental aromatase deficiency and a male fetus. High levels of circulating androgens allow sexual differentiation to proceed normally.  
❌ Intellectual disability:
Incorrect: Intellectual disability is not associated with placental aromatase deficiency.  
❌ Chromosomal mosaicism  :
Incorrect: Chromosomal mosaicism is characteristic of Turner syndrome, not placental aromatase deficiency.  
✅ Labioscrotal fusion  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obesity  :
Incorrect: Aromatase deficiency follows a different hormonal pathway that is not associated with the development of obesity.

questions.text: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the office for a routine well-child visit. The parent reports the patient has been feeding well and developing appropriately. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a cooperative child. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. The abdomen is soft with no organomegaly. Genitourinary examination demonstrates a circumcised penis of normal size. The right testis is located within the inguinal canal, and the left testis is palpable in the scrotum. If left untreated, which of the following complications is most likely to occur?
questions.solution:
