Cryptorchidism is a common congenital condition characterized by incomplete/partial descent of the testis into the scrotum. Approximately 80% of cryptorchid testes descend by the third month of life. If  descent has not occurred by six months of age, surgical correction should be considered, primarily to avoid the following complications:

  •  Testicular torsion: when malpositioned in the inguinal canal, the unfixed testis becomes prone to mobility, blunt trauma, and in particular, testicular torsion. 
  •  Testicular cancer: studies suggest the elevated temperature of the abdominal cavity promotes malignant transformation. Another theory postulates an underlying hormonal condition that predisposes some males to both cryptorchidism and testicular cancer. 
  • Subfertility/infertility: Males with a history of undescended testes are at increased risk of low sperm counts, poorer quality sperm, and lower fertility rates than males with normally descended testes. This decreased fertility occurs secondary to increased temperatures in the abdomen and inguinal canal, which impairs spermatogenesis.
Risk factors for this condition include prematurity, being small for gestational age at birth, and birth weight <2.5 kg. Several studies have also indicated a correlation with prenatal exposure to endocrine-disrupting chemicals. If bilateral cryptorchidism is observed, karyotype analysis and adrenal hormones and metabolites can evaluate for underlying congenital adrenal hyperplasia. In addition, luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), testosterone, müllerian inhibiting substance (MIS) can evaluate the presence and function of testicular tissue.  


Option Analysis

✅ Subfertility:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Penile carcinoma in situ:
Incorrect: A number of risk factors are associated with an increased risk of penile cancer, the most common of which includes lack of circumcision and human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. This child, who has cryptorchidism, is at increased risk of another condition.
❌ Erectile dysfunction:
Incorrect: Erectile dysfunction can be caused by numerous conditions, including peripheral arterial disease, medication related side-effects (e.g., SSRIs, beta-blockers), as well as penile disorders (e.g. Peyronie disease). Cryptorchidism is not associated with erectile dysfunction.
❌ Benign prostatic hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Benign prostatic hyperplasia is typically caused by increasing age and is not a complication of untreated cryptorchidism.
❌ Recurrent urinary tract infection:
Incorrect: Recurrent urinary tract infections in males are often due to anatomic disturbances, such as vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) or posterior urethral valves. However, this child, who has cryptorchidism, is at increased risk of another condition.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to her family physician for a routine checkup. The patient was diagnosed with androgen insensitivity syndrome during infancy, and her parents elected to delay gonadectomy until a later age. Physical examination is unremarkable. She declines a pelvic examination. If left untreated, which of the following complications is this patient at highest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with known androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS), which refers to a condition where patients have a defective androgen receptor such that they do not appropriately respond to circulating androgens. Patients suffering from this disorder are often genetically male, but phenotypically female, and they present with subtle to severe symptoms of under-masculinization. For this reason, diagnosis of AIS is subdivided into partial AIS, complete AIS and mild AIS, depending on symptom severity (see table below).

It is important for patients with AIS who have undescended testes to undergo gonadectomy, due to the high risk of malignant transformation (approximately 30% increased likelihood of developing testicular cancer). These tumors tend to be germ cell tumor gonadoblastoma, which occur in approximately 2% of all patients with undescended testicles (regardless of AIS status). While the majority of these tumors tend to be in-situ cancers, they can result in metastatic disease.  



Option Analysis

❌ Escalating phenotypic masculinization  :
Incorrect: Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) refers to an inability for the body to masculinize – meaning that the body does not masculinize in response to production of male-specific hormones like testosterone.  
✅ Increased risk of testicular cancer:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Testicular torsion  :
Incorrect: Testicular torsion occurs in phenotypic males; the spermatic cord twists upon itself, limiting circulation in the testicular artery and vein. This process does not occur in AIS patients, as the testicles have not descended properly.  
❌ Escalating phenotypic feminization  :
Incorrect: The presence of undescended testicles does not increase phenotypic feminization, as the pathophysiology of this disease involves failure of the androgen receptor to respond to androgens.  
❌ Increased risk of breast cancer  :
Incorrect: Delaying gonadectomy may lead to testicular cancer, not breast cancer.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents to his family physician accompanied by his parent due to concerns regarding delayed puberty. The patient’s parent expresses concern about a lack of secondary male sex characteristics compared to his sibling of the same age. The patient has a reserved demeanor and answers questions with one-word answers. The patient gets mostly C’s and some D’s in school. He has been picked on since starting school for his inability to smell when other students intentionally break wind in his presence. On physical examination, height and weight are near the 60th percentile for his age. The patient has absent pubic hair and small testes. A deficiency of which of the following hormones is most directly responsible for this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This vignette illustrates characteristic features of Kallman syndrome – a genetic disorder that prevents one from starting or finishing puberty. Kallmann syndrome falls under a subset of genetic disorders, termed hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, and patients with this disorder present with distinct reproductive and non-reproductive clinical features.

During the first 10 weeks of embryological development, gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) neurons migrate from their initial location in rostral nasopharynx, an area called the olfactory placode, through the cribriform plate and into the developing hypothalamus. Kallman syndrome is thought to arise from aberration of GnRH neuronal migration, which also affects neurons originating in the olfactory placode, leading to anosmia. The lack of GnRH in these patients ultimately leads to downstream absence of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle stimulating hormone (FSH), resulting in lack of secondary sexual characteristics and hair growth. Kallmann syndrome is significantly more common in males than females.  

Option Analysis

✅ Gonadotropin-releasing hormone  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Follicle Stimulating Hormone  :
Incorrect: While FSH is greatly decreased in this disorder, it is the lack of upstream GnRH which accounts for the physical manifestations of Kallman syndrome.  
❌ Luteinizing hormone  :
Incorrect: While LH is greatly decreased in this disorder, it is the lack of upstream GnRH which accounts for the physical manifestations of Kallman syndrome.  
❌ Testosterone:
Incorrect: This patient’s lack of secondary sexual characteristics is due to a lack of GnRH, not testosterone. This is further evidenced by this patient’s anosmia and hypogonadism (pathognomonic features of Kallmann Syndrome).  
❌ Corticotropin releasing hormone  :
Incorrect: Hypothalamic expression of CRH is unrelated to this patient’s hypogonadism. Corticotropin-releasing hormone stimulates cortisol secretion during times of sustained stress.
